awd_abstract_narration:
The 2024 Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop will focus on the latest advances in the fields of synthetic biology and biotechnology, bringing together key stakeholders from academia and industry who have aligned interests. The workshop’s program focuses on mammalian synthetic biology research, including organoid development, tissue engineering, synthetic circuits, RNA-based regulators, and synthetic reporters and recorders. A major goal of the workshop is to create an environment where a diverse group of researchers can gather and exchange information. Additionally, the conference aims to give students and early career professionals opportunities to share their work, to network with the foremost leaders in the field, and to develop their careers.

Mammalian synthetic biology is a rapidly growing and highly impactful area of research with important applications in biotechnology and medicine. This workshop aims to have scientific presentations from a diverse group of researchers, to have active participation by students who represent the future of the field, to promote interactions between academic and industry researchers, to provide a collaborative atmosphere that motivates new interdisciplinary research, and to have extensive participation from a variety of groups. The conference will enable professionals and young researchers to interact and learn through organized talks, panels, question and answer discussions, and poster sessions. The conference will feature a variety areas of mammalian synthetic biology, including organoid development, tissue engineering, synthetic circuits and RNA-based regulators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Conference: 2024 Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop

Project Outcomes Report
Award 2412586

 

The 2024 Mammalian Synthetic Biology Workshop (mSBW) took place August 6-7 at Boston University in Boston, MA. The event gathered leaders in synthetic biology and experts from other relevant fields to highlight and inspire cutting-edge synthetic biology research, emphasizing both basic and applied science. Workshop sessions included:

  • Synthetic Gene Regulation Approaches: synthetic biology approaches to understand and control gene expression. These include regulation of chromatin, transcription, RNA process and protein production.
  • Synthetic Biology for Therapeutics: new designs and engineering for biomolecular circuits for therapeutic applications and clinical translation.
  • Developmental, Multicellular and Regenerative Systems: novel approaches to programming cell fate and engineering multicellular communities for understanding cell-fate transitions, including in development and cancer
  • Foundational Technologies: tools to build the next generation of synthetic systems from molecules to cells.
  • Scalable Technologies & Artificial Intelligence: high-throughput measurements of DNE, RNA and protein functions are computational approaches to large-scale synthetic biology.
  • Synthetic Biology for Cancer: as specific mutations induce oncogenesis, synthetic biology tools can help understand the cascade of molecular events as cell transition into cancers.

With 231 attendees, this year’s event attendance grew by over 20% compared to 2023, indicating the continued growth of the community and need for a meeting in this field. Keynotes and invited talks from current and rising mammalian synthetic biology leaders allowed the audience to learn about the latest research, methodologies and best practices. Poster sessions provided trainees and early career professionals with an opportunity to present and receive feedback on their work. Networking events offered time for informal discussions to develop new connections and foster collaboration.

Conference speakers included:

  • Christopher Chen, Boston University
  • Stirling Churchman, Harvard Medical School
  • James Collins, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • Tal Danino, Columbia University
  • Shawdee Eshghi, Ginkgo Bioworks
  • Daniel Hammer, University of Pennsylvania
  • Naomi Handly, Octant
  • Isaac Hilton, Rice University
  • Albert Keung, North Carolina State University
  • Alec Nielsen, Asimov
  • Ritu Raman, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • Hirohide Saito, University of Tokyo
  • Nika Shakiba, University of Birtish Columbia
  • Jared Toettcher, Princeton University
  • Peter Wang, University of Southern California

Since its inception, mSBW has focused on inclusivity, aiming to be an affordable event for students, post-docs and early career faculty members. Offering registration rates below other comparable events makes it easier for people just starting their careers to be involved. It is particularly important for those early in their careers to attend mSBW, establishing their community and capitalizing on career development opportunities that can only be realized through in-person interactions.

NSF support allowed mSBW to maintain its low registration rates. This resulted in over 100 U.S.-based students/post-docs and over 20 U.S.-based assistant professors receiving subsidized registration. Additionally, of attendees who responded, 52% were from a demographic defined by the NSF as a historically underrepresented group in STEM. This numbers show the impact that the NSF’s registration support can have on engaging trainees, early career professionals and underrepresented groups in conferences aimed at learning and career development opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2024
Modified by: Evan Flach
